awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  OCT-Compatible Imaging Adaptor for Precision Vascular Access via Hollow-Bore Needles
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project supports development of a commercially viable real time optical imaging device to address the problem of failed first time vascular access.  Peripheral IV access (PIV) is the most common invasive procedure for all ages, races and clinical settings. In the United States alone, there are an estimated 230 million PIVs placed per year. First time IV access has a shockingly high failure rate of 35%-50%.  Multiple attempts result in pain and emotional distress, especially in the pediatric population where the failure rate is highest. The average cost of placing an IV on the first time is $69.76.  Three or more attempts doubles the cost to be greater than $125 per IV. When PIV access cannot be obtained the more invasive, risky and costly central IV access is used which increases the risk of blood borne infections as well as other complications. One central IV sourced infection can add 7-20 additional days of hospital length of stay and $56,000 of additional (unreimbursed) cost, adding as much as $2.3 billion in increased US intensive care unit costs each year.  These failure rates occur even though ultrasound and near infrared devices are available to improve first time IV access. 

In phase II, the project team will refine the hybrid Optical Coherence Tomography tipped imaging probe, customized for vascular access, and integrate it into a commercially viable system to fulfill goals not supported by any other imaging system: finding and recognizing veins; guiding the angiocath needle to the vein; acquiring intra lumen access on first attempt; and confirming intra lumen placement.  The system needs to be cost effective, durable and acceptable to a multitude of diverse clinicians. The disposable adapter probe will connect to a hand piece that will tactilely enable the clinician to actuate rotation and advancement of the optical probe to acquire data necessary to create clinically relevant 3D real time images.  The data are transmitted to a control unit for processing and then presented to a small form display such as smart phone. Research activity will be focused in developing the egonomically acceptable hand piece that does not interfere with  variable angular approaches to the vein. A critical part of the ongoing research will focus on software design for creating an optimal graphic user interface (GUI). Multiple form factors of the hand piece, the GUI, and visual display will be evaluated by practicing clinicians for final production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Venipuncture is the most common invasive procedure in medicine, with over 3 billion procedures performed worldwide per year mostly done ?blind?. Even with currently available imaging aids, failure rates are 20-30% in easy-to-access patients and 45-70% in difficult populations. 
   
Nowhere is this pain felt as much as in pediatrics. Customer discovery with over 250 clinicians has confirmed. Multiple IV access attempts reduce patient and parent satisfaction, and increasing hospital cost. Additionally, these catheters tend to fail quicker and need to be reinserted more often. Shockingly, 50% of IVs do not last more than 24hrs.
   
Vascular access represents an acute source of pain in the pediatric population for numerous reasons:
   1. Small vessels
   2. Vessels are in a setting of surplus adipose tissue, and are more difficult to locate 
   3. Hard to know if the pediatric vein is cannulated. 
   4. The clinician cannot know if the needle has gone too far and infiltrated the distal side of the vessel. 

If even 15% of the IV's placed could last for greater than 3 days without replacement it would prevent six million unnecessary intravenous catheter insertions leading to a savings in $60 million in health costs each year.

Our goal is -- one patient, one IV. WFMD aims to become the de-facto standard of care for placing pediatric peripheral IV?s that last for the duration of care.


By temporarily integrating imaging into the needle used to obtain IV access (a fundamental change in the way imaging is currently used), clinicians are able to manipulate the needle and engage patients as they are accustomed to, but with the added benefit of seeing what is directly in front of the needle. The SingleStick? aims to solve two major challenges of pediatric PIV access: 
   
   1. Helping clinicians find the vein and adjust the angle and trajectory of the needle appropriately. 
   2. By improving successful cannulation of the vessel and placement of the catheter with minimal damage to the vessel. 
   
   SingleStick? not only relegates the blind-stick to the past, but represents a transformational shift in the way imaging will be used for clinician guidance ? by enabling the practitioner to visualize and identify anatomical markers in-situ, via real-time visualization, without major modification of existing needles and technique. The SingleStick? will: 
   - Reduce the cost of PIV access 
   - Reduce # of central lines, 
   - Reduce pain, 
   - Reduce time/improve efficiency, 
   - Improve patient, parent & clinician satisfaction

With the NSF SBIR Phase II grant, WestFace Medical designed and developed a working prototype for the SingleStick imaging adapter. This adapter integrates within the hollow bore of standard vascular access needles and catheters (periperhal IV and central catheters) and provides the clinician with real time imaging in front of the needle. With this imaging the clinician can ensure first-time every-time access to the vessel. Additionally, the imaging can reduce complications and ensure the catheter is optimally positioned within the vessel lumen, increasing catheter latency and dwell times. The team has achieved a working prototype by effectively developing the four main components of the system which include:
   
   1. Disposable Imaging Adapter: The patented adapter integrates directly into the hollow bore of needle, providing imaging directly from the needle tip.
    
   2. Non-disposable handpiece: allows for the scanning that enables real-time imaging and allows advancement and retraction of the imaging probe.
    
   3. Imaging processor: The Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) laser and image processing equipment.
   
   4. Software: The software converts the OCT image into an easily interpreted user interface that shows directional guidance down to the needle. This guide is unlike current available medical imaging and is more simple to interpret than a standard ultrasound image. 

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2022
Modified by: Thomas Mowery
